div.head: THE EPISTLE TO the Courteous and Iudicious Reader.
div.p:
IT is an olde prouerbe, That nothing can bee perfect at the first inuention of it; and in an Arte that is new, the more that write of it, the better it is for the Learner; for from euery man hee may gleane somewhat: and the more any matter is argued, the more knowledge there will be had of the truth of the matter proposed, and the falshoodes will so much the sooner be espied. Therefore in reading the Booke of Magneticall Aduertisements, I obserued that the Author had beene industrious in some things; in other things somewhat forgetfull, deuising some things not so pertinent as hee esteemed they would bee: but no new thing was added, some old things mistaken, some things censured imperfectly:
wherevpon I haue taken alittle paines to make a suruey of this Booke; no way going about to examine all, lest I should seeme either too diligent or too curious; but clearing as well as I could, that which I tooke to be doubtfull, opening that which I thought to bee obscure, and where any thing was vnprofitably deuised, I made what vse I could of it, or else reiected it; and looke what I thought was mistaken, I haue answered, and made it manifest for all men easilie to vnderstand; wherein being desirous to satisfie all, I hope that I haue set a way open for euery man to enter in, and tread in the pathes of Truth. The particulars will be better vnderstood in the reading of both Bookes together, then can bee if some of them were here inserted, and therefore wishing the courteous and iudicious Reader health and benefit hereof, I cease,

closer.signed: Yours in all affection, M. R.
